tuv.seg: Sometimes in criminal prosecutions heard in lower courts, the judge may order the defendant to place a donation in the court poor box in lieu of conviction
Amanna i gcásanna coiriúla os comhair na gcúirteanna íochtaracha in Éirinn, d'fhéadfadh an breitheamh ordú a thabhairt don chosantóir síntiús a chur i mBosca na mBocht in áit a bheith ciontaithe
In other words, instead of being convicted and facing imprisonment or a statutory fine, the judge can order that the defendant donate a sum to a charity nominated by the judge

I bhfocail eile, in áit a bheith ciontaithe agus tréimhse príosúnachta, nó fíneáil reachtúil a bheith amach roimhe/roimpi, is féidir leis an mbreitheamh a ordú go mbronnan an cosantóir suim airgid ar charthanas ainmnithe ag an mbreitheamh
This sum of money is then lodged by the defendant with the court and paid over by the Fines Office of the Court to the charity in question
Cuireann an cosantóir an tsuim airgid seo i dtaisce sa chúirt, agus ansin íocann Oifig Fineála na Cúirte an t-airgead leis an gcarthanas atá i gceist
There is no apparent law in place that gives the judge this discretion
Níl aon dlí soiléir a thugann an chumhacht seo don bhreitheamh
The use of the court poor box, however, is a process that has evolved over the years
Is próiseas í úsáid Bhosca na mBocht áfach, a d'fhás thar na blianta
It appears to stem from the judge's common law jurisdiction to exercise his or her discretion in imposing penalties and/or other conditions
Is cosúil go n-éiríonn sé as dlínse dlí choitinn an bhreithimh a c(h)umhacht a chomhlíonadh agus é/í ag gearradh píonós agus/nó coinníollacha eile
In particular, this process often occurs in the lower courts (i.e., the District Court)
Go háirithe, tarlaíonn an próiseas seo sna cúirteanna íochtaracha (is é sin, an Chúirt Dhúchais)
In 2005 the Law Reform Commission published their Report on the court poor box: probation of offenders (pdf)
Í 2005 d’fhoilsigh an Coimisiún um Athchóiriú an Dlí a dtuarascáil Report on The Court Poor Box: Probation of Offenders (pdf)

In February 2014 the Department of Justice and Equality published the General Scheme of Criminal Justice (Community Sanctions) Bill which proposes to replace the poor box with a statutory Reparation Fund

I mí Feabhra 2014 d'fhoilsigh an Roinn Dlí agus Cirt agus Comhionannais an Scéim Ghinearálta um Bille Cheartas Coiriúil (Smachtbhannaí Pobail) um a bhfuil sé beartaithe a chur in ionad an bosca mbocht le Ciste Cúitimh reachtúil
Until new legislation is introduced however, the following information describes the current situation with regard to the court poor box
Go dtí go dtabharfar reachtaíocht nua isteach, áfach, déanann an t-eolas seo a leanas cur síos ar an staid mar atá faoi láthair i leith Bhosca Cúirte na mBocht in Éirinn
The most common reason for making a decision such as this is that, in the opinion of the judge, while the prosecution has proven its case, it is not appropriate to enter a conviction
Is é an fáth is coiteanta a ndéantar cinneadh mar sin ná, i dtuairim an bhreithimh, cé go bhfuil a gcás cruthaithe ag na cúisitheoirí, nach bhfuil sé oiriúnach ciontú a chur síos
For example, the judge may anticipate that the defendant will not commit any other offence
Mar shampla, má tá súil ag an mbreitheamh nach ndéanfaidh an cosantóir coir ar bith eile
For example, on the one hand, it could be argued that the prospect of appearing in court is a significant deterrent from crime for some citizens
Mar shampla, ar láimh amháin is féidir a áiteamh gur cosc suntasach ar choir é do roinnt saoránach a bheith ag súil le teacht os comhair cúirte
The fact that details of their personal lives and activities may become public knowledge can sometimes be enough to deter them from committing a crime again
Amanna nuair a smaoiníonn siad go mbeidh sonraí a saol pearsanta agus a ngníomhaíoctaí os comhair an phobail, cuireann sé sin iad ó choir a dhéanamh arís
In addition, having a conviction registered against you can significantly affect your life (i.e., employment prospects, career, business and social relationships, etc.)
Chomh maith leis sin, má bhíonn ciontú cláraithe i d'aghaidh, bíonn torthaí suntasacha ar do shaol (mar shampla súil le fostaíocht, slí bheatha, caidrimh gnó agus sóisialta, agus araile)
For this reason, where the court feels that the citizen will not re-offend, the judge can choose to impose a donation to the court poor box
Mar gheall air sin nuair a cheapann an chúirt nach ndéanfaidh an saoránach coir ar bith eile, is féidir leis an mbreitheamh síntiús do Bhosca na mBocht a roghnú mar phíonós
On the other hand, however, concerns have been expressed in Ireland as to the need to ensure equal treatment for offenders from different economic backgrounds
Ar an láimh eile, áfach, is cúis imní in Éirinn nach bhfuiltear cinnte an gcaitear le ciontóirí as culraí eacnamaíochta difriúla ar bhealach cothrom
There is also a significant question as to the lack of accountability regarding the use of funds
Tá ceist shuntasach chomh maith ann faoin easpa freagrachta maidir le húsáid an airgid
For example, some people feel that having a court poor box is a way out of conviction for some citizens who can afford to pay the fine
Mar shampla ceapann daoine áirithe gur bealach éalaithe ó chiontú é Bosca na mBocht do shaoránaigh a bhfuil sé d'acmhainn acu an fhíneáil a íoc
Other individuals who cannot afford the fine may have no option but to have their conviction registered against them
B'fhéidir nach mbeadh an dara rogha ag daoine nach bhfuil sé d'acmhainn acu an fhíneáil a íoc, ach an ciontú a bheith cláraithe ina n-aghaidh
There are also concerns that donations to the court poor box deprives the Irish Government of fines that should in ordinary circumstances be imposed
Is cúis imní é chomh maith go gcoinníonn na síntiúis do Bhosca na mBocht fíneálacha a ghearrfaí de ghnáth ó Rialtas na hÉireann
There is currently no specific law governing court poor boxes
Níl dlí ar bith in Éirinn a rialaíonn Boscaí na mBocht sna cúirteanna
Where an accused makes a payment to the poor box, the judge usually applies the Probation of Offenders Act 1908 or imposes a suspended sentence
Nuair a dhéanann an cúisí íocaíocht do Bhosca na mBocht, de ghnáth cuireann an breitheamh an tAcht Promhaidh i bhfeidhm nó ghearrann sé/sí pionós ar fionraí
It is intended to reform the current court poor box system
Tá sé i gceist a athchóiriú ar an gcóras bosca mbocht cúirte
Until new legislation is in place, the court poor box system is still in force
Go dtí go bhfuil an reachtaíocht nua i bhfeidhm, tá an córas bosca mbocht cúirte fós i bhfeidhm
Donations to the court poor box imposed by a judge can vary in amount, depending on the offence
Is féidir athruithe a bheith ar shuimeanna síntiús do Bhosca na mBocht a ghearrann breitheamh ag brath ar an gcoir

If a judge orders that you make a donation to the court poor box and you have the funds to pay, the Court Registrar in court on the day will collect the payment and issue you with a receipt. If you do not have the funds with you on the day but can afford to pay, your case may be adjourned for a period (i.e., a month, three months, etc.)

Má ordaíonn breitheamh duit síntiús a dhéanamh do Bhosca na mBocht agus má tá an t-airgead agat é a íoc, baileoidh an Cláraitheoir Cúirte sa chúirt ar an lá an íocaíocht agus eiseoidh sé/sí admháil duit
You are then recalled to court and you pay the donation. Donations are then forwarded to the relevant charity/organisation by the court
Ansin cuireann an chúirt na híocaíochtaí ar aghaidh go dtí an carthanas/eagraíocht chuí
If you do not have the funds to pay or you choose not to make a donation, a conviction for your offence will be registered against you
Mura mbíonn an t-airgead agat, nó má roghnaíonn tú gan síntiús a dhéanamh, clárófar ciontú i dtaobh do choire i d'aghaidh
